video.title: Maths for Programmers: Sets (What Is A Rational Number?)
video.description:
We're busy people who learn to code, then practice by building projects for nonprofits. Learn Full-stack JavaScript, build a portfolio, and get great references with our open source community.

Join our community at https://freecodecamp.com
Follow us on twitter: https://twitter.com/freecodecamp
Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/freecodecamp
Follow Quincy on Quora: https://www.quora.com/Quincy-Larson

topLevelComment.author: anaisana
topLevelComment.text: Ohh he almost divided by 0 there, I was a little scared, but it’s ok since b≠0... great stuff though wow thanks

replies.author: Dhaval Makvana
replies.text: In school I was taught any number that can represented in the for a/b, as the guys has shown the set notation, is a rational number. So all we had to do to prove a number to be rational is bring it in the form of a/b

topLevelComment.author: dragonhunter250utub
topLevelComment.text: 9.9999 repeating will never equal 10, maybe you were talking about something else.

replies.author: Cat O Call
replies.text: 0.333... + 0.333...  + 0.333... = 1 maybe this is an artifact of the limitations of the decimal system. If we use a base 12 system 1/3 becomes 3 and avoids  the decimal point entirely.

replies.author: jack taylor
replies.text: Yeah, it’s funny how most people would agree that 1/3 = .333... but would disagree that .999... = 1 when in fact, they say precisely the same thing lol

replies.author: Shawn S
replies.text: 9.99repeating precisely equals 10.  Since no number exists between them, they are the same number.

replies.author: Сергей Кириллов
replies.text:
@Telly Ipock
I don't know whether it is possible to record 2.(2) in a different way.
However, there are two quite informative articles which may help you to understand this subject:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/0.999...
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Repeating_decimal

replies.author: Telly Ipock
replies.text: Does this only applied to 9.999... or numbers like that? What about 2.222222... ??
